title.narrative: Education in Emergencies for Conflict Affected IDP children in Basateen Camp, in Sirqat, in Iraq.

description.narrative:
According to the UNHCR FLASH UPDATE 2nd April 2017, Continuous flow of internally displaced persons (IDPs) from west Mosul to Hammam Al-Alil, Qairah, and Basateen. The government has opened a new camp south of Mosul, Jad’ah 5 camp, where 2,283 families (about 13,000 individuals) have been transferred between 30 March and 1 April. IDPs are fleeing areas recently retaken by the Iraqi Security Forces (ISF), and areas of west Mosul still under armed groups’ control. Although the government and some NGOs are distributing food in a small number of retaken neighborhoods in west Mosul, lack of food and potable water reportedly remains a considerable challenge for civilians in west Mosul. Some reported that they hadn’t had access to potable water for up to 45 days. IDPs from areas still under armed groups’ control interviewed by UNHCR highlighted the enormous risks taken during their flight, including targeting by snipers and IEDs.
The influx of the IDPs is expected to increase where families will flee from western Mosul towards Basateen area where Islamic Relief Iraq in partnership with UNOCHA has already installed 1000 tents and ready to receive the IDPs in the said area.
In response, Islamic Relief Worldwide, Iraq (IRW-Iraq) aims to provide children and adolescents affected by the conflict access to safe and protective learning spaces inclusive of psychosocial activities. This project will target 3600 children (age 6-17 of which 50% are girls) among the displaced families in Basateen camp. The project will establish Temporary Learning Spaces (TLSs) in the camp, identify teachers with a special focus on female teachers among the arrived families in the camp in coordination with the Education Office, distribute student and teachers kits to camp children and selected teachers respectively. Islamic Relief Iraq has already coordinated this intervention with the Unicef to provide the following supplies: Caravans, Students and teachers kits, recreational kits, and schools box. Unicef has made their commitments to provide the above mentioned supplies. The proposed six months project will offer the targeted children with non-formal education program at Temporary Learning Space (TLS) through the installation of 24 tents/Caravan and equipping them with the required educational material, school boxes, students kits, and teachers kits. In addition, the project will provide improvement training to 48 teacher (30 women and 18 men). The project will also establish child club for Psycho-social support and recreational activities where the focus will be on the most vulnerable boys and girls. The project team will form community education council to raise awareness among parents/ caregivers on providing good parenting, emotional support, and basic child protection concepts.
